{{multiple issues| {{globalize/US|date=March 2012}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} }}
'''Property management''' is the operation, control, and oversight of [[real estate]]. Management indicates a need to be cared for, monitored and accountability given for its useful life and condition. This is much akin to the role of [[management]] in any [[business]].
Property management is also the management of personal property, equipment, tooling, and physical capital assets that are acquired and used to build, repair, and maintain end item deliverables. Property management involves the processes, systems, and manpower required to manage the [[Property Cycle|life cycle]] of all acquired property as defined above including acquisition, control, accountability, responsibility, maintenance, utilization, and disposition.
For example, an owner of a single family may engage the services of a property management company. The company will then advertise the rental property, handle tenant inquiries, screen applicants, select suitable candidates, draw up a lease agreement, conduct a move in inspection, move the tenant(s) into the property and collect rental income. The company will then coordinate any maintenance issues,supply the owner(s) with financial statements and any relevant information regarding the property etc.
== Roles ==
There are many facets to this profession, including managing the accounts and finances of the real estate properties, and participating in or initiating litigation with tenants, contractors and insurance agencies. Litigation is at times considered a separate function, set aside for trained attorneys. Although a person will be responsible for this in his/her job description, there may be an attorney working under a property manager. Special attention is given to landlord/tenant law and most commonly evictions, non-payment, harassment, reduction of pre-arranged services, and public nuisance are legal subjects that gain the most amount of attention from property managers. Therefore, it is a necessity that a property manager be current with applicable municipal, county, state and Federal Fair Housing laws and practices.
== Licensing ==
=== Australia === Every state of [[Australia]] has different licensing and compliance requirements. Generally, to be able to provide property management services, a real estate licence is required. State of Victoria Australia information.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theocguide.com.au|title=theOCguide – Owners Corporation Guide – Melbourne, Victoria|website=www.theocguide.com.au}}</ref>
All tenancy applications received are reference checked inclusive of identification, means of income, previous tenancy references and workplace references.{{cn|date=February 2018}} Additionally tenants are checked against the National Tenancy Information Centre of Australia which records details of defaulting tenants.{{cn|date=February 2018}}
=== Canada === In Canada, the laws governing property management and landlord/tenant relations are, generally speaking, a Provincial responsibility. Each Province and Territory makes its own laws on these matters. In most cases any person or company can offer property management services, and there are licensing requirements. Other than specific laws in each Province and Territory governing these matters, they are governed by English Common Law, except in the Province of Quebec where the Civil Code is used in place of English Common Law. In some cities, the Provincial Legislation is supplemented by City by-laws.
British Columbia – The licensing of property managers is regulated by the provincial government and licensing by the BC Real Estate Council (RECBC). The Real Estate Council of British Columbia is a regulatory agency established by the provincial government in 1958. Its mandate is to protect the public interest by enforcing the licensing and licensee conduct requirements of the Real Estate Services Act. The Council is responsible for licensing individuals and brokerages engaged in real estate sales, rental and strata property management. The Council also enforces entry qualifications, investigates complaints against licensees and imposes disciplinary sanctions under the Act.
The Council is responsible for ensuring that the interests of consumers who use the services of real estate licensees are adequately protected against wrongful actions by the licensees. A wrongful action may be deliberate or may be the consequence of inadequate exercise of reasonable judgment by a licensee in carrying out their duties and responsibilities.
The Council is responsible for determining what is appropriate education in real estate matters for individuals seeking to be licensed as real estate practitioners and arranging for licensing courses and examinations as part of the qualification requirement for licensing. Under the authority of the Council, licensing courses are delivered by the UBC Sauder School of Business, Real Estate Division.
Ontario – no licensing is required to operate, however ACMO – the [[Association of Condo Managers of Ontario]] is a self-governing body for certification and designation of its members who run buildings with more than 600 units. (RECO) the [[Real Estate Council of Ontario]], regulates licensed realtors in Ontario. The provincial government is revising its [[Ontario Condominium Act, 1998|condominium act]]. After public consultation, it hopes to put forth legislation during the 2015–2016 session requiring Condo Management firms and staff or condo employees and boards to be accredited.
Saskatchewan and Alberta both require property managers to hold a real estate license.
=== India === In India, there is no statutory regulation of property management companies, real estate agents or developers. In 2013, a Real Estate Regulation and Development Bill was passed by the Union Cabinet, but has yet to take effect. The bill seeks to set up 3 regulatory bodies in the country. The Real Estate Regulation and Development Bill was passed by the Union Cabinet in early 2016 and this is expected to bring about a sea change in the management of real estate in India.
=== New Zealand === Commercial Property Management leasing agents in New Zealand are required to have a real estate agents licence and operate and audited trust bank account. Commercial leases are covered by the Property Law Act 1952.
Residential property management in New Zealand is an unlicensed and unregulated industry. Property managers in New Zealand do not require any registration, minimum knowledge or skill. The New Zealand Government reviewed whether all forms of property management need any legislation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/property-managers-review-underway|title=Property managers review underway|website=The Beehive|language=en-nz|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref> Following completion of the review, the Associate Minister of Justice, Hon Nathan Guy, announced on 2 July 2009 that no new occupational regulation would be imposed on property managers<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/no-additional-regulation-property-managers|title=No additional regulation for property managers|website=The Beehive|language=en-nz|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref> in part due to there already being existing laws which could be used to protect consumers.
New Zealand licensed Real Estate Agents may offer Residential Property Management service with qualified Real Estate Agents as Property Managers, or property manager's working under the Licensed Real estate agency. Member Agents are supposed to adhere to the Real Estate Institute of New Zealand property management code of practice<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.reinz.co.nz/Media/Default/pdf/Codes%20of%20Practice/REINZ%20Code%20of%20Practice%20for%20RPM%20-%20changes%202016.pdf|title=REINZ Property Management Code of Practice|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> which according to the REAA outlines industry best practices for dealing with the public. Critics state the Real Estate Agents Authority complaint committee as having less scope or jurisdiction for adverse judgement against negligent Property Management licences as they would otherwise to those in "real estate agency work",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.consumer.org.nz/articles/property-managers#article-complaints|title=Consumer Article Property Management Complaints|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> unsatisfactory property management conduct cases can receive findings of "no further action" as opposed to "unsatisfactory conduct"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2008/0066/latest/DLM1152058.html|title=Real Estate Agents Act 2008 No 66 (as at 01 September 2017), Public Act 72 Unsatisfactory conduct – New Zealand Legislation|website=www.legislation.govt.nz|language=en-NZ|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref> due to "conduct unrelated to estate agency work".<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://decisions.dotnous.com/reaa/v2/abstract.aspx?case=2269|title=C07283 Abstract {{!}} Complaint Determinations {{!}} Real Estate Agents Authority|website=decisions.dotnous.com|language=en-NZ|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref> Best practice guidelines<ref name=":0" /> imply Licensed Real Estate agencies conducting property management business should collect rent through an audited trust account which brings some certainty to the security of the Landlord and Tenants rental Monies though REAA cases implies that this is not always so.<ref name=":1" />
The Residential Tenancies Act 1986 sets out the rights and responsibilities of residential landlords and tenants, including the requirement to have a written tenancy agreement and the need to lodge tenancy bonds (if one is required) with the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment. The Tenancy Tribunal<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.justice.govt.nz/tribunals/tenancy/about/|title=About the Tribunal {{!}} New Zealand Ministry of Justice|website=www.justice.govt.nz|language=en-NZ|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref> and its adjudicators/mediators hear and make judgement on disputes (between landlord and tenants) in relation to any breaches of The Residential Tenancies Act 1986 and The Unit Titles Act 2010.
The Unit Titles Act 2010 sets out the law for the ownership and management of unit title developments, where multiple owners each hold a unit title. The Act covers the set-up of such developments, body corporate governance, the rights and obligations of the body corporate and unit owners, disclosure between buyers and sellers, dispute resolution etc. The Unit Titles Regulations 2011 provide operational guidelines. The body corporate is responsible for financial and administrative functions relating to the common property and the development. All unit owners are members of the body corporate. A body corporate can delegate some of its powers and duties to a body corporate committee and a professional body corporate manager may be contracted to provide services.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dbh.govt.nz/unit-titles-intro-to-uta-2010|title=Building performance|publisher=Department of Building and Housing NZ}}</ref>
=== Republic of Ireland === In the [[Republic of Ireland]], there is no legal obligation to form a property management company. However, management companies are generally formed to manage multi-unit developments, and must then follow the general rules of company law in terms of ownership and administration.
Since July 2012, it has become mandatory for all property service providers, including property management companies, to be registered and fully licensed by the Property Services Regulatory Authority of Ireland.
The [[National Consumer Agency]] (NCA) has campaigned in this area, and in September 2008 it launched a website explaining consumer rights. The NCA does not have a legislative or regulatory function in the area, unless a consumer complaint is in relation to a breach of consumer law.
=== Romania === No specific regulatory or licensing body exists at this time (November 2012). However, under Financial business law, Any business offering Property Management as a chargeable, fee earning act of commerce may only do so if such services are listed in their Company Acts of Constitutions, i.e., legally pre-declared list of business activities. Under Romanian law, no business can derive income from any such service that is not declared in this way and should be demonstrable upon request by the client of legal entities.
=== United Kingdom === In the United Kingdom there is no statutory regulation concerning property management companies. Companies which manage rented residential property are often members of the [[Association of Residential Letting Agents]]. Companies or individual [[landlord]]s who accept [[tenancy deposit]]s for "[[Assured shorthold tenancy|assured shorthold tenancies]]" (the usual form of residential tenancy) are required by statute to be members of a [[Tenancy Deposit Scheme (England and Wales)|Tenancy Deposit Scheme]].
Companies which manage apartment buildings are often members of the [[Association of Residential Managing Agents]] (ARMA).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arma.org.uk |title=AMRA |date=19 March 2013 |publisher=Amber Management|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> ARMA is a trade association for firms that manage private residential leasehold blocks of flats in England & Wales. ARMA promotes high standards of leasehold management by providing advice, training and guidance to its member firms of managing agents. ARMA also produces guidance materials for leaseholders and Residents Management Companies. With over 280 firms in membership, ARMA also campaigns for improvements in the legislation governing the leasehold sector.
=== United States === Most states, such as [[New York (state)|New York]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chasse|first1=Terrance|title=New York State Property Management Law|url=http://www.nycpropertypartners.com/new-york-state-property-management-law/|publisher=NYCPP|quote=all New York property management companies must {{sic|posses}} a real estate broker’s license. This license is required for such activities as renting to list, negotiating the rental of a property, collecting rent and placing tenants on behalf of a landlord client. There are very limited exemptions to this requirement.|date=2014-12-31}}</ref> [[Texas]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Property Management requirements in Texas|url=http://www.allpropertymanagement.com/propertylaw/property-management-law-in-texas.html|publisher=AllPropertyMangement.com|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref> and Colorado,<ref>{{cite web|title=CP-27|url=http://cdn.colorado.gov/cs/Satellite?blobcol=urldata&blobheadername1=Content-Disposition&blobheadername2=Content-Type&blobheadervalue1=inline%3B+filename%3D%22Performance+of+Residential+Leasing+and+Property+Management+Function+CP-27.pdf%22&blobheadervalue2=application%2Fpdf&blobkey=id&blobtable=MungoBlobs&blobwhere=1251871577703&ssbinary=true|publisher=colorado.gov|accessdate=2 January 2015|quote=Pursuant to C.R.S. § 12-61-101(2)(a)&(b), the leasing and subsequent management of real estate for a fee or compensation, is included among the activities for which a license is required.}}</ref> require property management companies to be licensed real estate brokers if they are collecting rent, listing properties for rent or helping negotiate leases and doing inspections as a third-party. A property manager may be a licensed real estate salesperson but generally they must be working under a licensed real estate broker. Most states have a public license check system on-line for anyone holding a real estate salesperson or real estate broker's license.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.dre.ca.gov/PublicASP/pplinfo.asp|title=Public License Information|publisher=California Bureau of Real Estate|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> A few states, such as Idaho, Maine, and Vermont do not require property managers to have real estate licenses. Other states, such as Montana, Oregon, and South Carolina, allow property managers to work under a property management license rather than a broker's license.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allpropertymanagement.com/propertylaw/|title=Property Management Requirements by State|date=10 September 2012|publisher=All Property Management|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
Owners who manage their own property are not required to have a real estate license in many states; however, they must at least have a business license to rent out their own home. Owners who do not live near the rental property may be required, by local government, to hire the services of a property management company{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}. Some states with high tourism numbers, such as Hawaii<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/hawaii/articles/2017-03-23/hawaii-committees-pass-new-versions-of-vacation-rental-bills|title=Hawaii Committees Pass New Versions of Vacation Rental Bills|last=|first=|date=23 March 2017|website=U.S. News & World Report|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=21 March 2018}}</ref>, have strict property management rules.
In California, third-party apartment property managers must be licensed with the [[California Bureau of Real Estate]] as a [[Real estate broker|Real Estate Broker]]. A broker's license is required for any person or company that, for compensation, leases or rents or offers to lease or rent, or places for rent, or solicits listing of places for rent, or solicits for prospective tenants, or negotiates the sale, purchase or exchanges of leases on real property, or on a business opportunity, or collects rents from real property, or improvements thereon, or from business opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.onecle.com/california/business/10131.html|title=California Business and Professions Code Section 10131 – California Attorney Resources – California Laws|website=law.onecle.com}}</ref> California Code of Regulations, Title 25, section 42, requires property owners of apartment buildings with 16 or more units to have on-site resident managers living on their properties. There is no such requirement for apartment buildings with less than 16 units.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/jun/02/realestate/re-aptlife2|title=On-Site Managers Aren't Always Required|first=KEVIN|last=POSTEMA|date=2 June 2002|publisher=|newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
The designation [[Real Estate Broker]] is often confused by those unfamiliar with terms of the industry as [[Realtor]], [[Real estate broker|Agent]], or [[Salesperson]].
=== Panama ===
In order to be able to manage properties in Panama, at that moment, no licenses are required, as long as the company is focussed on managing properties. Nevertheless, a real estate company which plans to buy and sell properties requieres a license.
=== Kenya === In [[Kenya]] the [[Estate Agents Registration Board]] (EARB)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://estateagentsboard.or.ke |title=Estate Agents Registration Board (EARB) |date=25 October 2018 |publisher=estateagentsboard.or.ke |accessdate=25 October 2018}}</ref> is the regulatory body for estate agency practice in Kenya and it derives its mandate from Estate Agents Act, 1984 Cap 533<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.saccotek.co.ke/docs/Estate%20Agents%20Act%2017%20of%201984%20Cap%20533.pdf |title=Estate Agents Act Cap 533 |last=|first=|date=|publisher=saccotek.co.ke |website=|access-date=}}</ref> which was operationalized in 1987. As per the provisions of the Act, the Board is charged with the responsibility of registering estate agents and ensuring that the competence and conduct of practicing estate agents are of a standard sufficiently high to ensure the protection of the public. The Board also keeps a list of registered members on its website that is accessible to members of public, In ACCORDANCE with section 9 of the Estate Agents Act.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://estateagentsboard.or.ke/members.html |title=registered members list |date=25 October 2018 |publisher=estateagentsboard.or.ke |accessdate=25 October 2018}}</ref> The Board recently drafted a proposal with a set of amendments to the Estate Agents Act<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.saccotek.co.ke/docs/Proposed%20Amendments%20to%20the%20Estate%20Agents%20Act%20Cap%20533-2017.pdf |title=Proposed Amendments to the Estate Agents Act Cap 533-2017 |last=|publisher=saccotek.co.ke |first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Associations that real estate agents and property developers can join include: [[Kenya Property Developers Association]] (KPDA)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kpda.or.ke |title=Kenya Property Developers Association - Development Brings Development |date=25 October 2018 |publisher=kpda.or.ke |accessdate=25 October 2018}}</ref> KPDA was established in [[Nairobi]] in 2006 as the representative body of the residential, commercial and industrial property development sector in [[Kenya]]. It is an emerging Business Member Organisation which works in proactive partnership with policy-makers, financiers and citizens to ensure that the property development industry grows rapidly but in an organized, efficient, economical and ethical manner. Another Association is the [[Kenya Professional Realtors Association]] (KPRA) <ref>{{cite web|url=https://kprakenya.co.ke |title=KPRA - The Voice Of Real Estate Professionals In Kenya |date=25 October 2018 |publisher=Kangai Technologies|accessdate=25 October 2018}}</ref>. KPRA is a professional organization that advances [[Real Estate]] Professional Services for Real Estate Professionals who buy, sell and manage real estate and related businesses. KPRA Provides a variety of services to its members including professional designation, training certification, education and legislative representation, as well as membership in local and regional businesses affiliated with KPRA.
== Professional designations ==
[[Building Owners and Managers Association]] (BOMA International) offers industry-standard designations that certify the training to property managers:<ref>{{cite web|title=About BOMA International|url=http://www.boma.org/ABOUT/Pages/default.aspx|publisher=BOMA International|accessdate=5 October 2015}}</ref> * [[Real Property Administrator]] (RPA) * Facilities Management Administrator (FMA) * Systems Maintenance Administrator (SMA) * Systems Maintenance Technician (SMT)
[[Institute of Real Estate Management]] (IREM) * [[Certified Property Manager]] (CPM) * Accredited Residential Manager (ARM) * Accredited Commercial Manager (ACoM) * Accredited Management Organization (AMO)
[[Manufactured Housing Institute]] (MHI) * Accredited Community Manager (ACM) * Professional Housing Consultant (PHC)
[[National Apartment Association]] (NAA) has the following designations: * Certified Apartment Manager (CAM) * Certified Apartment Property Supervisor (CAPS) * Certificate for Apartment Maintenance Technicians (CAMT) * National Apartment Leasing Professional (NALP)
[[National Association of Residential Property Managers]] (NARPM) offers designations to certify ethical and professional standards of conduct for property managers:<ref>http://www.narpm.org/ National</ref> * Residential Management Professional (RMP)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/residential-management-professional/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324174922/http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/residential-management-professional/ |archivedate=2016-03-24 |df= }}</ref> * Master Property Manager (MPM)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/master-property-manager/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324174738/http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/master-property-manager/ |archivedate=2016-03-24 |df= }}</ref> * Certified Support Specialist (CSS)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/certified-support-specialist/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324173921/http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/certified-support-specialist/ |archivedate=2016-03-24 |df= }}</ref> * Certified Residential Management Company (CRMC)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/certified-residential-management-company/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324174145/http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/certified-residential-management-company/ |archivedate=2016-03-24 |df= }}</ref> * Certified Maintenance Coordinator (CMC)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/certified-maintenance-coordinator/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324174434/http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/certified-maintenance-coordinator/ |archivedate=2016-03-24 |df= }}</ref> * Certified Residential Management Bookkeeper (CRMB)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/certified-residential-management-bookkeeper-crmb/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324180321/http://www.narpm.org/education/designations-and-certification/certified-residential-management-bookkeeper-crmb/ |archivedate=2016-03-24 |df= }}</ref>
State-specific designations include the following: * California – [[Certified Community Association Manager]] (CCAM) * Florida – Community Association Manager (CAM) * Minnesota – Certified Community Association Manager (CCAM) * Minnesota – Certified Residential Manager (CRM)
The [[Community Associations Institute]] also has designations in the United States for residential property managers who manage planned communities such as Condominiums, Home Owners Associations and Cooperatives. National designations include: * Association Management Specialist (AMS) * Certified Manager of Community Associations (CMCA) * Large Scale Manager (LSM) * Professional Community Association Manager (PCAM) – Highest designation awarded.
The [[National Association of Home Builders]] has a specialized designation for the affordable housing industry through the Low Income Housing Tax Credit (LIHTC) program: • Housing Credit Certified Professional (HCCP)
In the UK: * [[Association of Residential Managing Agents]] (ARMA) * [[Institute of Residential Property Management]] (IRPM)
In Kenya: * [[ Estate Agents Registration Board]] (EARB) * [[ Kenya Property Developers Association]] (KPDA) * [[ Kenya Professional Realtors Association]] (KPRA)
== Property management software == Property management software continues to grow in popularity and importance. As it decreases in price, smaller companies and amateur property managers are able to function using some of the same best practices and efficiency as larger companies. Online asset management software (OPMS, or online property management software) has been a major cause of the price declines. In addition to the core property management software options, there is a quickly growing number of closely related software products being introduced to the industry.{{cn|date=November 2016}}
Property management system, also known as a PMS, is a comprehensive software application used to cover objectives like coordinating the operational functions of the front office, bookings, communication with guests, planning, reporting etc. This kind of software is used to run large-scale hotels and vacation properties.
== Business models ==
=== Percentage of rent === This is the most common model, and is used by property management companies in the residential space that manage multi-home units and single family homes. The property owner in this case signs a property management agreement with the company, giving the latter the right to let it out to new tenants and collect rent. The owners don't usually even know who the tenants are. The property management company usually keeps 10-15% of the rent amount, and shares the rest with the property owner.
=== Fixed fee === This is the most common revenue model used by companies when monitoring empty homes or empty land sites. The work here involves monitoring the property and ensuring that it is safe and secure, and reporting back to the owner. As there is no income from these properties, a fixed monthly fee is usually charged to the owner.
=== Guaranteed rent === This model is also used in the residential space, but mostly for small units in high demand locations. Here, the company signs a rental agreement with the owner and pays them a fixed rent. As per the agreement, the company is given the right to sublet the property for a higher rent. The company's income is the difference between the two rents. As is evident, in this case, the company minimizes the rent paid to the owner, which is usually lower than market rates.
=== Revenue share === This model applies to the service apartment space and other commercial establishments, such as retail or business centers that generate revenue. In this case, the property manager signs an agreement with the property owner, with the right to convert the property into a revenue generating business such as a business center, service apartment, etc. Instead of paying rent to the owner, the management company shares a percentage of revenue.{{cn|date=February 2017}} There are also hybrid structures here, where a combination of a fixed rent and a share of revenue is shared with the property owner.{{cn|date=February 2017}}

'''Ralf Gathmann''' (born June 4, 1965) is a German entrepreneur.<ref name="bfmtv">{{cite news|url=https://dirigeants.bfmtv.com/Ralf-GATHMANN-3464208/|title=Ralf GATHMANN|work=BFMBusiness|accessdate=17 August 2017|language=fr}}</ref> Gathmann is the [[chief executive officer]] of [[Corys TESS|CORYS]],<ref>{{cite journal|title=Ralf Gathmann: Executive Profile & Biography|journal=Bloomberg|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=208428458&privcapId=30295717&previousCapId=30295717&previousTitle=Corys%20T.E.S.S.%20S.A.S.|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Harris|first1=Ken|title=Jane's world railways, 1999-2000|date=1999|publisher=Jane's Information Group|location=Coulsdon, UK|isbn=9780710619228|page=628|edition=41st}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Clarke|first1=Jackie|editor1-last=Harris|editor1-first=Ken|title=Jane's world railways 2008-2009|date=2008|publisher=Jane's|location=Coulsdon|isbn=9780710628619|page=769}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ralf Gathmann: "De nouveaux murs pour accompagner le futur de Corys T.E.S.S."|url=http://www.presences-grenoble.fr/people/ralf-gathmann-ldquo-de-nouveaux-murs-pour-accompagner-le-futur-de-corys-t-e-s-s-rdquo--19191.kjsp|accessdate=17 August 2017|work=Grenoble|date=1 May 2011|language=fr-FR}}</ref> which supplies training and engineering simulators to Transportation, Power, Oil&Gas and Chemical industries. He is also the former secretary of Rail Training International Limited. He holds a master's degree in [[Physics]] and a Ph.D. degree in [[engineering mechanics]].<ref name=RalfGathmann>{{cite news|title=Ralf Gathmann|url=https://www.lesechos.fr/28/05/2008/LesEchos/20181-074-ECH_ralf-gathmann.htm|accessdate=17 August 2017|work=Les Echos FR|date=28 May 2008}}</ref>
==Career== In 1993, Gathmann joined [[Corys TESS|Corys]] R & D. He did well working in the company and two years later, in 1995, he became a Deputy Technical Director. Later he took the position of Director of the [[Rail transport|Rail]] Sector Business Unit and since 2003, he held the position of Deputy Chief Operating Officer. Ralf Gathmann is appointed as a Managing Director of [[Corys TESS|Corys]] in 2008.<ref name=RalfGathmann/>
Then he developed the rail business and boosted its international expansion, before joining the operational management, the general management and then the positions of [[CEO]] in 2009.
This German national had worked at Rail Training International Limited from 2002 to 2003. Another company where Ralf Gathmann was appointed (on 2000) was Rail Training International Limited. He worked there until 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ralf Gathmann: "De nouveaux murs pour accompagner le futur de Corys T.E.S.S."|url=http://www.grenoble-ecobiz.biz/jcms/rec_141853/fr/ralf-gathmann-de-nouveaux-murs-pour-accompagner-le-futur-de-corys-tess|accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>
===Corys=== [[Corys TESS|Corys]] is a [[France|French]] company based in [[Grenoble]], is a world reference in training and engineering simulators.
==See also== * [[Corys TESS|Corys]] * [[Grenoble|Grenoble]]

{{Infobox person | name = Raoul Warocqué | image = | alt = | caption = Portrait of Raoul Warocqué | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1870|02|04}} | birth_place = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1917|05|28|1870|02|04}} | death_place = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | nationality = Belgian | other_names = | occupation = Industrialist, politician, philanthropist | known_for = Founding the [[Musée royal de Mariemont]] }} '''Raoul Warocqué''' ([[Brussels]], 4 February 1870 – [[Brussels]], 28 May 1917), was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] industrialist from [[Wallonia]].
==Biography== Raoul was the great-grandson of [[Nicolas Warocqué]], the founder of the prominent Warocqué family. His father was [[Arthur Warocqué]], (1835–80),<ref>[https://archive.is/20120907064944/http://www.morlanwelz.be/histoire/vandeneynde/arthur_warocque.htm Arthur Warocqué (French)]</ref> a promotor of Belgian horticulture, after whom the [[Araceae|arum]] ''[[Anthurium warocqueanum]]'' was named.<ref>{{cite book | author=[[James Herbert Veitch]]| title=Hortus Veitchii| publisher=[[Caradoc Doy]] | year=2006|edition=reprint|pages=227| isbn=0-9553515-0-2}}</ref>
Warocqué was a [[philanthropist]] and a believer in [[paternalism]]. He was a [[freemason]] of the [[Grand Orient of Belgium]], Belgian [[patriotism|patriot]] and a [[monarchist|royalist]]. At the [[Universite Libre de Bruxelles]] (ULB), he participated in the ''Jeune Garde libérale'' (Young Liberal Guard).
[[File:Université de Mons-Hainaut (1).JPG|thumb|Building of the former ''École de Commerce'' in [[Mons]] which Warocqué founded]] Raoul Warocqué made the coal mines of [[Morlanwelz|Mariemont]] successful, and at 21 years of age had established a considerable fortune. A careful investment policy made him the richest man in Belgium at the beginning of the 20th century. His industrial ventures were numerous, such as in the coal mines of [[Campine]] as well as in other industrial sectors including [[Clabecq]], Gas and Electricity of Hainaut, railroads and coal mines in [[China]], tobacco in [[Portugal]], and others.
As a politician he was mayor of [[Morlanwelz]] and liberal deputy of [[Thuin]]. In [[Mariemont, Belgium|Mariemont]] and in [[Hainaut (province)|Hainaut]], he founded liberal organizations. He supported bills favorable to the [[working class]], while at the same time he was opposed to the right to strike. His most noted interventions relate to the [[Belgian Congo]], military service, compulsory education and coal mining.
As a philanthropist, he created open dormitories in Brussels (1891) which distributed soup and bread to the poor. He supported the ULB, the ''Ecole des Mines'' (School of Mining), and founded the ''Institut commercial'' (Commercial Institute) in [[Mons]] as well as the ''Athénée du Centre'' (Central Athenaeum) in [[Morlanwelz]], an orphanage, a childcare facility, a maternity hospital, and some other institutions.
He was also one of the financiers of the [[List of world expositions|World Fair of Brussels]] ([[Brussels International (1897)|1897]] and 1910) and of [[Charleroi]] (1911). He fell ill and died during [[World War I]], in 1917. On his death in 1917, his art and antiquities collections were donated to the Belgian state and now form the basis for the [[Musée royal de Mariemont]].

==Further reading== *{{cite book |last1=Faider |first1=Paul |title=Biographie nationale |date=1938 |publisher=Académie royale de Belgique |location=Brussels |at=col. 95-9 |volume=27 |chapter-url=http://www.academieroyale.be/fr/la-biographie-nationale-personnalites-detail/personnalites/raoul-warocque/Vrai/ |chapter=Warocqué, Raoul}}

{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=November 2016}} {{notability|Companies|date=December 2015}} }} {{Infobox software |logo = Samepage icon.png |name = Samepage |developer = Samepage Labs, Inc.<ref>{{cite web|title=AppStore - Samepage|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/samepage/id632534443?mt=8|publisher=iTunes}}</ref> |programming_language = [[Java (programming language)|Java]] |language = English, Czech, German, Spanish, French, Italian, Portuguese, Russian, Japanese |genre = [[Collaborative software]] |license = [[Software as a service]] |website = {{url|https://www.samepage.io}} }}
'''Samepage''' is a [[collaboration software]] platform for online teams, offering collaborative tools such as [[online chat]], [[Videotelephony]], [[task management]], [[file sharing]], and real-time [[document collaboration]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Seeing ‘broken’ collaboration, Samepage readies ‘content with context’|url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/12/17/seeing-broken-collaboration-samepage-readies-content-with-context/|accessdate=7 December 2015|agency=Venturebeat|date=14 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Samepage Review and Rating|url = https://www.pcmag.com/review/354945/samepage|website = PCMag|accessdate = 2017-08-21}}</ref>
Samepage, previously a division of [[Kerio Technologies]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Kerio Technologies|url=http://www.kerio.com/company}}</ref> who developed early versions of the platform under the name of Kerio Workspace,<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Kerio Workspace|url=http://www.kerio.com/tags/kerio-workspace|website=Kerio Technologies}}</ref> was officially launched in 2013. Before 2013, the platform was only available as a completely on-premises server software package. In 2013, it was completely retooled as a cloud-hosted [[Software as a Service]] platform.
In 2014, Samepage offered its users integration with other web platforms such as Zapier, Dropbox, Box, Google Drive, OneDrive, Vimeo, YouTube, and Google Maps.<ref>{{cite web|title=Samepage updates its collaboration service with Box, Dropbox support|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/2882792/samepage-updates-its-collaboration-service-with-box-dropbox-support.html|website=PCWorld}}</ref> In 2015, Samepage announced their partnership with [[Startup Grind]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Samepage Announces Startup Grind 2015 Partnership|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/samepage-announces-startup-grind-2015-partnership-300033365.html|accessdate=7 December 2015|publisher=PR Newswire|date=12 July 2015}}</ref> Shortly afterward, Samepage was named as one of only three Hot Vendors in Content and Collaboration by Aragon Research<ref>{{cite news|title=Aragon Research|url=https://aragonresearch.com/special-reports/special-report-aragon-research-hot-vendors-for-2015-part-i/|accessdate=7 December 2015|work=Hot Vendors For 2015|publisher=Aragon Research|date=28 May 2015}}</ref> and announced their partnership with [[Regus]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Samepage Pro for the Regus Marketplace|url=http://marketplace.regus.com/deal/Mp33RB/1_year_Samepage_Pro_subscription_FREE|website=Regus Marketplace|accessdate=7 December 2015}}</ref>
Now as a standalone platform, Samepage is ranked 260th in US startups by Startupranking.com.<ref>{{Cite web|title = United States Top 201 - 300 {{!}} Startup Ranking|url = http://www.startupranking.com/top/united-states/4#startup_samepage-io|website = StartupRanking|accessdate = 2018-03-26}}</ref> Samepage has been reviewed throughout its development by Tech Republic,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Social collaboration in the cloud with Samepage - TechRepublic|url = http://www.techrepublic.com/blog/it-consultant/social-collaboration-in-the-cloud-with-samepage/|website = TechRepublic|accessdate = 2015-12-10}}</ref> Macworld,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Kerio Samepage.io review: streamlined, remotely hosted, team management tool|url = http://www.macworld.co.uk/review/utilities/kerio-samepageio-review-streamlined-remotely-hosted-team-management-tool-3449204/|website = Macworld UK|accessdate = 2015-12-10|language = en-GB}}</ref> and IT World Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Samepage courts business users with easy collaboration option|url = http://www.itworldcanada.com/article/samepage-courts-business-users-with-easy-collaboration-option/373681|website = IT World Canada|accessdate = 2015-12-10}}</ref>
In 2017, [[Entrepreneurs' Organization]] announced a global partnership with Samepage, designating Samepage as their officially endorsed collaboration tool. <ref>{{Cite web|title = Entrepreneurs’ Organization Announces Global Partnership with Samepage®|url = https://www.eonetwork.org/pressreleaselibrary/eo-announces-global-partnership-with-samepage|website = Entrepreneurs' Organization|accessdate = 2017-12-07}}</ref>
In June 2018, Samepage secured seed financing from [https://www.reflexcapital.com/?lang=en Reflex Capital.] <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/collaboration-software-platform-samepage-secures-financing-from-reflex-capital-300669546.html|title=Collaboration Software Platform Samepage Secures Financing from Reflex Capital|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of collaborative software]]

revision.text:
{{COI|date=November 2013}}
'''Small Business Majority''' is a [[small business]] [[advocacy]] organization in the [[United States]]. It is based in [[San Francisco]], with offices in [[Washington, D.C.]], [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], [[New York City]], [[Denver]] and [[St. Louis]].
Small Business Majority performs opinion polling and writes studies to highlight questions and opinions on issues affecting small businesses. It uses this information to provide small business owners with information on how [[law]]s affect their bottom line, and to educate [[policymaker]]s on a diverse set of issues that they can then advocate for, such as [[healthcare reform]], access to credit and [[Job creation program|job creation]].
== History == John Arensmeyer founded Small Business Majority in 2005.
== Healthcare reform == Small Business Majority opines on how the [[healthcare system]] affects small businesses, and lobbies to influence the implementation of [[Health care reform in the United States|healthcare reform]].
During the push for passage of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], Small Business Majority lobbied in support for the act. Policy papers and materials the organization developed were used by healthcare reform advocates and small business groups to push the message of small business support for healthcare legislation. Small Business Majority organized small business forums at the [[White House]] with cabinet members and with the [[Senate Small Business Committee|US Senate Small Business Committee]], along with House committees and [[caucus]]es on healthcare issues. The ''[[National Journal]]'' noted that Small Business Majority's work on this issue "gained prominence on [[Capitol Hill]] and at the White House during the health care debate.<ref>Vaida, Bara. "Steering Small Biz Left." ''National Journal''. January 9, 2010.</ref> " Small Business Majority continues to inform [[lawmaker]]s, [[employer]]s and the public on key provisions of the law, and on the various aspects of its implementation, particularly state [[health insurance exchange]]s and the small business healthcare tax credits.
==Clean Energy== Since Small Business Majority began working on [[clean energy]] issues in 2010, the organization has commissioned a wide body of opinion research to determine small business owners’ views on clean energy policies and the perceived effect of those policies on their businesses and the [[economy]] as a whole. The organization also conducts in-depth economic research analyzing the economic impact of state and federal clean energy policies on small firms.
Small Business Majority uses its scientific opinion polling and economic research to lobby for clean energy measures. This has included meetings with national and state policymakers including [[U.S. senators]], representatives and [[Obama administration]] officials.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://smallbusinessmajority.org Small Business Majority's website]
[[Category:Business organizations based in the United States]]

page.title: Small and medium-sized enterprises in Azerbaijan

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2018}}
[[Small and medium-sized enterprises]] are called as KOS (kiçik və orta sahibkarlıq) or KOM (kiçik və orta müəssisələr) in [[Azerbaijan]]. SMEs have a leading position in the provision of economic growth and employment in Azerbaijan.
== Classification of SMEs == Azerbaijan also gave their categorization both relating to the amount of employees work at the company and annual turnover. Categorization of enterprises is indicated like below:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taxes.gov.az/modul.php?name=qanun&news=1091|title=- Qanunvericilik|website=Taxes.Gov.Az|language=en|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |'''Categorization of enterprises relating to their size''' |'''Number of employees''' |'''Annual turnover (AZN)''' |- |Small enterprises |< 25 |< 200 000 |- |Medium-sized enterprises |25 < 125 |200 000 < 1 250 000 |- |Large enterprises |125 < |1 250 000 < |} Governmental Statistic Committee defined this classification by taking into account various economic fields as below.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stat.gov.az/source/entrepreneurship/?lang=en|title=Small entrepreneurship in Azerbaijan {{!}} The State Statistical Committee of the Republic of Azerbaijan|last=(www.anarsamadov.net)|first=Anar Samadov|date=|website=The State Statistical Committee of the Republic of Azerbaijan|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |'''The category of entrepreneurship''' |'''Size of employees''' |'''Annual turnover (AZN)''' |- |Industry and construction |< 50 |< 500 000 |- |Agriculture |< 25 |< 250 000 |- |Wholesale trade |< 15 |< 1000 000 |- |Retail trade, transport,
service and other economic activities
types |< 10 |< 250 000 |} Small and medium-sized enterprises divided into two groups in Azerbaijan. * Individual entrepreneurs, so without creating legal person the sole owner of the enterprise. Individual entrepreneurs are persons involved in the business sphere without the formation of any legal entity and possess unlimited liability. * Small and medium-sized enterprises, that is, legal entities, which individual entrepreneurs legally considered as small businesses. Individuals who registered as a legal person classifies according to two kinds of indicators: the amount of employees and in accordance with its annual turnover. In term of the number of enterprises and employees, individual enterprises occupy the main part of the small and medium-sized business field. According to the data of the Statistics Committee for the year 2015, the number of small businesses in all economic sectors of the country, was 196 327. The number of small entrepreneurs has increased in 2015 about 9 429 people compared to 2014. In addition, 178 163 of them were individual entrepreneurs. Individual entrepreneur mostly agglomerated in the sectors, especially trade, and where take more revenues instead of minimum investments. Only a little amount of entrepreneurs takes part in business activities, which require high early investments and make profit in a long-term. On average, individual entrepreneurs employ less people and by this way, they decrease their expenditures and make more profit.
Legal entities registered by central administrations of ministries and agencies, and inspected carefully by them. Small enterprise is an entrepreneurship that controlled by legal entity and indicated in the disposal of the Ministry Cabinet. In this disposal the main principles for small and medium-sized enterprises are indicated.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cesd.az/new/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/CESD_Report-SMEs_Azerbaijan.pdf|title=Small and Medium Entrepreneurship in Azerbaijan; Country Assessment|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Programs for SME development == Direct the development of entrepreneurship in Azerbaijan started in 1990s. On December 12, 1992 government established "Regulations of the Republic of Azerbaijan National Entrepreneurship Support Fund". The approval of this fund let small and medium-sized enterprises take advantage from preferential loans. However, until 2001 the mechanism of the delivery to the entrepreneurship entities did not work properly. [[Heydar Aliyev]]’s on August 27, 2002 issued decree resulted the approval of "Regulations on National Entrepreneurship Support Fund of Azerbaijan Republic" and " The use of fund of National Entrepreneurship Support Fund of Azerbaijan Guidelines” was directed to the development of a mechanism for financing of investment projects of entrepreneurs. The began to issue loans with lower interest rates in the national currency, as well as, identification of the grace period to the first two-thirds parts of loans and credit’s low percentage caused arising interest to these credits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://anfes.gov.az/en/|title=Azerbaijan Ministry Of Economy National Fund For Entrepreneurship Support|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Strategic road map for the development of SMEs ===
SME development in the country based on the Strategic Road Map defined in order to achieve the strategic goals and to ensure maximum use of the opportunities identified as a strategic objective as follows:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mida.gov.az/documents/Ki%C3%A7ik_v%C9%99_orta_sahibkarl%C4%B1q_s%C9%99viyy%C9%99sind%C9%99_istehlak_mallar%C4%B1n%C4%B1n_istehsal%C4%B1na_dair.pdf|title=Strategic Road Map of Azerbaijan for the Production and Consumption of Goods at the Level of Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * Further improvement of the regulatory framework in the business environment in order to enhance the impact of the SME into [[Gross domestic product|GDP]] * Ensuring affordable and effective access to financing resources in order to create a sustainable network of SMEs * Internationalization of SMEs and increase access to foreign markets in order to increase the country's foreign exchange reserves and ensure compliance with international standards of goods produced in the country * Increasing the supply of quality products and services within the development of skilled workforce and development of SMEs focusing on regional markets * Strengthening of research and development and promotion of innovation in order to increase the competitiveness of SMEs Strategic Road Map defines the short, medium and long term directions of the economic reforms and development in SMEs. There are three main strategic views:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ecoreform.az/store//media/islahat_icmali/aprel/SME_eng.pdf|title=AZERBAIJAN ECONOMIC REFORMS REVIEW|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * until 2020 * the long-term view until 2025 * target view since 2025
=== Single window principle ===
[[Single-window system|"Single window" system]] applied based on the presidential decree issued on April 30, 2007. This principle provided for the registration of business entities and started to implement their online registration. Based on the principle [[E-government|E-Government]] portal has been created and implementation of the system started in 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://azertag.az/en/xeber/UNECE_HOLDS_SEMINAR_ON_SINGLE_WINDOW_PRINCIPLE_IN_BAKU-593335|title=UNECE HOLDS SEMINAR ON "SINGLE WINDOW" PRINCIPLE IN BAKU|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of companies of Azerbaijan]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Economy of Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Small and medium-sized enterprises]]

'''Thomas Beecham''' (3 December 1820 – 6 April 1907) was the founder of [[Beechams]], a large [[pharmaceutical]] businesses.
==Career== [[Image:BeechamsBuilding.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Beecham's Clock Tower built in 1877 in [[St Helens, Merseyside]] today serving as the College Administrative centre.]] Born in [[Curbridge, Oxfordshire|Curbridge]] in [[Oxfordshire]], Beecham became a [[shepherd]]'s boy at the age of 8 and it is in this role that he learnt about [[herbal]] [[medicine]].<ref name=odnb>{{cite ODNB|id=30669|title=Beecham, Thomas (1820–1907)| first=T. A. B.|last=Corley}}</ref>
For a while he worked as the village postman in [[Kidlington]] but in 1847 he moved to [[Wigan]] where he started selling [[Beecham's Pills]] which were a [[laxative]].<ref name=odnb/> By 1859 he was based in [[St Helens, Merseyside|St Helens]] where he started advertising as well as selling his pills.<ref name=odnb/> He created a network of agents throughout [[Lancashire]] and [[Yorkshire]] and by 1880 he had expanded his business so much that he was able to open his first factory.<ref name=odnb/>
In 1893 he moved to [[Southport]] where he fully retired within three years.<ref name=odnb/> He died in [[Southport]] in 1907 and is buried in [[St Helens, Merseyside|St Helens]].<ref name=odnb/>
==Family== In 1847 he married Jane Evans and together they went on to have two sons and two daughters.<ref name=odnb/> He subsequently married Sarah Pemberton in 1873 and Mary Sawell in 1879.<ref name=odnb/>
His elder son was [[Sir Joseph Beecham, 1st Baronet]], and his grandson was the noted conductor Sir [[Thomas Beecham]]. His younger son was William Eardley Beecham.<ref>{{cite DNB12|wstitle=Beecham, Thomas |first=Charles Donald|last=Maclean}}</ref> Another great grandchild was the poet [[Audrey Beecham]].<ref name=aud>Rachel Trickett, ‘Beecham, (Helen) Audrey (1915–1989)’, ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2012 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/60731, accessed 13 March 2017]</ref>

revision.text:
{{Merge|Al-Walid bin Ahmed Al Juffali|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Walid Juffali |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Walid Ahmed Juffali |birth_date = 30 April 1955 |birth_place = |death_date = {{death date and age|2016|07|20|1955|04|30|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Zurich]], Switzerland |residence = |nationality = Saudi |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = chairman of [[E. A. Juffali and Brothers]] |education = [[Le Rosey]] |alma_mater = [[University of San Diego]]
[[Imperial College London]] |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = £4 billion (June 2015) |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |boards = |religion = |spouse = Basma Al-Sulaiman (1980–2000)
Christina Estrada (2001–14)
Loujain Adada (m. 2012) |partner = |children = Six; three with Basma Al-Sulaiman, one with Christina Estrada and two with Loujain Adada |parents = [[Ahmed Juffali|Ahmed Abdullah Juffali]]
Su’ad Juffali |relations = [[Khaled Juffali]] (brother)
Ebrahim Juffali (brother)
Ali Juffali (brother) |website = }} '''Walid Ahmed Juffali''' (30 April 1955 – 20 July 2016) ({{lang-ar|وليد أحمد الجفالي}}) was a Saudi [[billionaire]] heir and businessman. He was the chairman of [[E. A. Juffali and Brothers]], one of Saudi Arabia's largest companies. His July 2016 divorce settlement of £75 million, shortly before his death from cancer, was the then largest such settlement in English legal history. ==Early life and education== Juffali was born on 30 April 1955,{{cite news|title=Walid Juffali, Saudi businessman – obituary|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/obituaries/2016/07/24/walid-juffali-saudi-businessman--obituary/|accessdate=25 July 2016|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|date=24 July 2016}} the son of [[Ahmed Juffali|Ahmed Abdullah Juffali]] (1924–1994),{{cite web|title=The Al Juffali family|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/arabian-business-rich-list-2010-367763.html?view=profile&itemid=367819|website=arabianbusiness|accessdate=11 November 2015}} the founder of [[E. A. Juffali and Brothers]], one of Saudi Arabia's largest companies.{{cite book|author=Stig Stenslie|title=Regime Stability in Saudi Arabia: The Challenge of Succession|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-g81rF4Zga4C&pg=PA60|accessdate=18 November 2015|date=21 August 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-51157-8|page=60}} His younger brother is [[Khaled Juffali]], and his sister is Maha Juffali.{{cite news|title=Strength in numbers|url=http://www.philanthropyage.org/2013/04/23/strength-in-numbers/|accessdate=11 November 2015|work=philanthropyage|date=23 April 2013}} He received a bachelor's degree from the [[University of San Diego]], California in 1977.{{cite web|title=Brain Forum Press Kit, page 10|url=http://thebrainforum.org/donwloads/Press_Kit.pdf|website=thebrainforum|accessdate=18 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=Dr. Walid Juffali|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Walid-Juffali/-1800396499|website=zoominfo|accessdate=18 November 2015}} In 2012, he received a doctorate in [[neuroscience]] from [[Imperial College London]].{{cite web|title=CBIT Alumni/Past Staff|url=http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/bioinspiredtechnology/people/alumni|website=Imperial College|accessdate=18 November 2015}} His PhD thesis was entitled, "A Novel Algorithm for Detection and Prediction of Neural Anomalies", and his supervisor was [[Chris Toumazou]].{{cite web|title=Completed PhD Theses|url=http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/bioinspiredtechnology/research/phdcomplete|website=Imperial College|accessdate=18 November 2015}} ==Career== Juffali was the chairman of [[E. A. Juffali and Brothers]], a position he has held since at least 2005.{{cite news|title=Entrepreneurial Reality Show, "The Investor"|url=http://www.albawaba.com/news/mbc-signs-walid-juffali-front-new-entrepreneurial-reality-show-investor-0|accessdate=18 November 2015|work=Albawaba|date=11 December 2005}} In 2005, Juffali was also chairman of [[Saudi American Bank]], deputy chairman of the Jeddah Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and Honorary Consul-General for Denmark. In December 2005, the [[Middle East Broadcasting Corporation]] (MBC) announced that Juffali would host its entrepreneurial reality show, ''The Investor'', which would be shown early in 2006. In her book ''Arab Television Today'', Naomi Sakr, compared the show to ''[[The Apprentice (TV series)|The Apprentice]]'', but noted that each of the 13 pairs of would-be entrepreneurs had to be from the same family, to reflect the "family aspect of business in the Arab world".{{cite book|author=Naomi Sakr|title=Arab Television Today|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zhpGsXK5EPYC&pg=PA116|accessdate=18 November 2015|date=15 December 2007|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1-84511-564-7|page=116}} Juffali also had a separate company, W Investments, a private wealth management company. The CEO is [[Jamil El Imad]], who is also managing director and chief scientist of his NeuroPro company.{{cite web|title=Executive Management Team|url=http://www.neuropro.ch/about/management-team/|website=neuropro|accessdate=18 November 2015}} ==Legal immunity== On 9 November 2015, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that Juffali had gained [[legal immunity]] in the UK, having been appointed as [[St Lucia]]'s "Permanent Representative" to the [[International Maritime Organization]] (IMO), which is headquartered in London.{{cite news |last1=Blair |first1=David |title= Saudi billionaire gains legal immunity in Britain with career as Caribbean diplomat |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/saudiarabia/11984928/Saudi-billionaire-gains-legal-immunity-in-Britain-with-career-as-Caribbean-diplomat.html |accessdate=11 November 2015 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location= London |date=9 November 2015}} Two days later, St Lucia's Office of the Prime Minister issued a statement, confirming that Juffali was appointed to the role in April 2014, "that all necessary due diligence was done prior to the appointment", and it declined the request from his ex-wife's lawyers to "lift the diplomatic immunity of Dr. Juffali to compel Dr. Juffali to testify in the civil suit ... this is a civil matter in which it does not desire to get involved."{{cite press release |title=Statement on Dr. Walid Juffali |url= http://education.govt.lc/news/statement-on-dr-walid-juffali |accessdate=18 November 2015 |publisher=St Lucia Ministry of Education, Human Resource Development and Labour |date=11 November 2015}} On 26 December 2015, ''The Daily Telegraph'' reported that it understood that the British Foreign Office had intervened to ask St Lucia to waive Juffali's immunity, amid concerns that he was using it to protect his wealth from his ex-wife during divorce proceedings.{{cite news |last1=Alexander |first1=Harriet |title=Britain intervenes to strip Saudi billionaire of diplomatic immunity ahead of divorce case |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/centralamericaandthecaribbean/saintlucia/12070077/Britain-intervenes-to-strip-Saudi-billionaire-of-diplomatic-immunity-ahead-of-divorce-case.html |accessdate=2 January 2016 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location= London |date=26 December 2015}} On 21 January 2016, ''The Daily Telegraph'' reported that the High Court had ordered [[Philip Hammond]], the British Foreign Secretary to certify whether Juffali had been formally accepted by the UK as a diplomat representing St Lucia, as his ex-wife's lawyer stated that Juffali had never attended an IMO meeting.{{cite news |last1=Blair |first1=David |title=Philip Hammond ordered to certify if Saudi billionaire Walid Juffali is a Caribbean diplomat |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/centralamericaandthecaribbean/saintlucia/12111257/Philip-Hammond-ordered-to-certify-if-Saudi-billionaire-Walid-Juffali-is-a-Caribbean-diplomat.html |accessdate=28 January 2016 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location= London |date=21 January 2016}} The judge lifted restrictions on reporting his ex-wife's claim that Juffali was seriously ill with cancer in a Swiss hospital since, if he were to die before the case is concluded, her claim would become irrelevant, and she and their daughter would receive no further monthly payments.{{cite news |last1=Blair |first1=David |title=Saudi billionaire in London court battle is 'suffering from cancer', says ex-wife |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/centralamericaandthecaribbean/saintlucia/12113293/Saudi-billionaire-in-London-court-battle-is-suffering-from-cancer-says-ex-wife.html |accessdate=28 January 2016 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location= London |date=21 January 2016}} In February 2016, the High Court dismissed Juffali's claim of diplomatic immunity as 'spurious'. Juffali appealed the judgment to the Court of Appeal, and was supported by an intervention from the Foreign Secretary.{{cite news |last1=Ramesh |first1=Randeep |title=Hammond criticises judge for stripping diplomatic immunity from Saudi billionaire |url= https://www.theguardian.com/law/2016/mar/22/hammond-criticises-judge-for-stripping-diplomatic-immunity-from-saudi-billionaire |accessdate=22 March 2016 |work=The Guardian |location= London |date=22 March 2016}} The Court of Appeal overturned the High Court's dismissal of Juffali's immunity, but ruled that his immunity was not relevant to the divorce claim, which it allowed to proceed.{{cite news |last1=Ramesh |first1=Randeep |title=Ex-wife of Saudi billionaire wins right to claim slice of his fortune |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/22/ex-wife-saudi-billionaire-sheikh-walid-juffali-right-claim-slice-fortune |accessdate=23 March 2016 |work=The Guardian |location= London |date=22 March 2016}} The divorce of Juffali and his second wife, Christina Estrada, was concluded in the British courts in July 2016 with Estrada being awarded £75 million, the largest such settlement in English legal history.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/08/former-pirelli-calendar-model-awarded-75m-in-largest-divorce-set/|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|title=Former Pirelli calendar model awarded £75m in largest divorce settlement in English legal history|accessdate=9 September 2016}} ==Death== On 20 July 2016, Juffali died in Zurich, Switzerland, after a lengthy period with cancer. {{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Amie|title=Saudi billionaire dies just two weeks after his supermodel ex-wife was awarded £75m in high court divorce settlement|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3703765/Ex-supermodel-awarded-75million-kind-divorce-settlement-Saudi-billionaire-ex-wait-payout-died.html|accessdate=23 July 2016|work=Daily Mail|date=22 July 2016}} ==Personal life== Juffali's first wife was fellow Saudi, Basma Al-Sulaiman, who received £40 million in a divorce settlement in 2000. They married in [[Jeddah]], Saudi Arabia in 1980, where they lived in a marble palace. Guests of Juffali in Jeddah included [[Margaret Thatcher]], [[John Major]] and [[George H. W. Bush]].{{cite news |last1=Kay |first1=Richard |title= The beauty who cost lover Pounds 40m |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/columnists/article-228583/The-beauty-cost-lover-Pounds-40m.html |accessdate=11 November 2015 |work=Daily Mail |location= London |date=23 January 2004}} They had three children.{{cite news |title= Mother in dark on Christina's 'baby' |url= https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-77754608.html |work=Daily Mail |location= London |author= Dempster, Nigel |date=31 August 2001 |accessdate=11 November 2015}} In 2001 Juffali married Christina Estrada, an American former [[Pirelli Calendar]] model, but they divorced in 2014. Estrada started divorce proceedings in 2012, after he married Loujain Adada (Saudi law allows up to four wives), and has made a claim against Juffali for at least his three UK properties, which include a seven-bedroom home in [[Knightsbridge]], London, in a converted church, valued in total at about £60 million. Juffali and Estrada have a teenage daughter.{{cite news|last1=Roberts|first1=Elizabeth|title=Ex-model once linked to Prince Andrew 'in divorce battle with husband worth £4bn'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/11673981/Ex-model-once-linked-to-Prince-Andrew-in-divorce-battle-with-husband-worth-4bn.html|accessdate=11 November 2015|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=14 June 2015}} Juffali also owned [[Bishopsgate House, Egham|Bishopsgate House]] in [[Egham]], Surrey, which he acquired from his parents in about 2001.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/property-and-architecture/inside-british-homes-saudi-billionaire-walid-juffali-three-butlers/|title=Inside the British homes of Saudi billionaire Walid Juffali... with three butlers, six gardeners, £4m of art|first=Rosa|last=Silverman|date=3 February 2018|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=12 February 2018|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}} There were "three butlers, six gardeners, five maids, two laundry girls, two drivers, two personal assistants, two nannies and an estate manager on the staff". Juffali's art collection, estimated at £4 million, will be auctioned onsite at Bishopsgate House by Bonham's on 26 March 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.bonhams.com/press_release/25446/|title=Bonhams : THE WALID JUFFALI COLLECTIONOffered by Bonhams Onsite at Bishopsgate House, Surrey|author=|date=|website=www.bonhams.com|accessdate=12 February 2018}} Juffali was one of three Saudi businessmen who donated at least $1 million to the [[Clinton Presidential Center]].{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Distant donors|url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=wes_ttda&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503798530&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=The Times|issue=69486|date=20 November 2008|page=48|subscription=yes|via=The Times Digital Archive}} In November 2012, Juffali married the 25-year-old Lebanese model and TV presenter Loujain Adada in Venice. They had two children together.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3680325/Court-ruling-ex-supermodels-divorce-money-battle-Saudi-billionaire.html|publisher=dailymail.co.uk|title=Christina Estrada in huge divorce case is awarded £75m from Sheikh Walid Juffali | Daily Mail Online|accessdate=9 September 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Juffali, Walid}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of Imperial College London]] [[Category:Juffali family|Walid]] [[Category:Knights of St. Sylvester]] [[Category:People from Jeddah]] [[Category:People from Knightsbridge]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian billionaires]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]] [[Category:University of San Diego alumni]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox MP |honorific-prefix = |name = William Barber |honorific-suffix = |image = William Henry Peter Barber.jpg |alt = |caption = |constituency_MP4 = [[Newtown (New Zealand electorate)|Newtown]] |parliament4 = New Zealand |term_start4 = 1902 |term_end4 = 1908 |predecessor4 = new electorate |successor4 = electorate abolished |office5 = [[Wellington City Council]]lor |term_start5 = 1891 |term_end5 = 1905 |term_start6 = 1910 |term_end6 = 1919 |birth_date = 10 September 1857 |birth_place = [[Wellington]], New Zealand |death_date = 15 January 1943 |death_place = [[Wellington]], New Zealand |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |birthname = |nationality = |party = [[New Zealand Liberal Party|Liberal]] |otherparty = [[New Liberal Party (New Zealand)|New Liberal Party]] |spouse = Emily Clarke |relations = |children = 5 |alma_mater = |profession = |religion = |signature = }} '''William Henry Peter Barber''' (10 September 1857 – 15 January 1943) was a New Zealand [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Newtown (New Zealand electorate)|Newtown]] in [[Wellington]].
==Early life and family== Born in Wellington in 1857, Barber was educated at St Peter's School. He began work in his father's dyeing firm of Barber and Company, and eventually became its head. He married Emily Clarke, of Somerset, England in 1879, and had three sons and two daughters.<ref name="EP obit">{{cite news|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19430115.2.26 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post]] |volume=CXXXV|issue=12|date=15 January 1943|page=3|title=Obituary Mr. W.H.P. Barber|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref>
==Member of Parliament== {{NZ parlbox header|nolist=true|align=left}} {{NZ parlbox |start={{NZ election link year|1902}} |end=1905 |term=15th |electorate={{NZ electorate link|Newtown}} |party=New Zealand Liberal Party }} {{NZ parlbox allegiance |start=1905 |end= |party=New Liberal Party (New Zealand) }} {{NZ parlbox |start={{NZ election link year|1905}} |end=1908 |term=16th |electorate=Newtown |party=New Zealand Liberal Party }} {{end}} William Barber represented the [[Wellington]] electorate of [[Newtown (New Zealand electorate)|Newtown]] for the whole of its existence, from [[New Zealand general election, 1902|1902]] to 1908. In [[New Zealand general election, 1908|1908]] he was defeated for the reconstituted electorate of [[Wellington South (New Zealand electorate)|Wellington South]].
===New Liberal Party=== Barber was associated with the [[New Liberal Party (New Zealand)|New Liberal Party]]. His favourite idea was one shared by the other New Liberals-that the institutions of local government should be strengthened and given more scope and power. He heartily supported [[Harry Ell]]'s 1904 Municipal Corporations Bill, which provided for borough councils to hold referenda.<ref>{{citation |journal = New Zealand Parliamentary Debates |volume = 123 |pages = 372}}</ref>
Barber also advocated state fire insurance, state coal mines, and the old radical favourite, reduction of taxes on the necessities of life. However, he did not favour the elective executive.<ref>{{citation |journal = New Zealand Times |date = 24 November 1902|page=7}}</ref>
==Other activities== He served as a director of the Wellington Woollen Company (chairman at the time of his death), and chairman of directors of the Wellington Opera House Company. He was elected to the [[Wellington City Council]] in 1891 and served as a councilor for 26 years.<ref name="EP obit" /> He contested the [[Wellington City mayoral election, 1905|1905 Wellington City mayoral election]] and came second, beaten by [[Thomas William Hislop]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=NZFL19050429.2.19.1 |work = The Free Lance |page=16 |title=Wellington City Council |date= 29 April 1905 |accessdate= 15 March 2016 | volume=V | issue=43 }}</ref> He was a member of the Hutt Valley Electric Power Board (retired 1933); director of Wellington Deposit and Mortgage Company; chairman of the Wellington College Board of Governors (1924–31) and a member of the Kauri Timber Royal Commission.<ref name="EP obit"/>
In 1935, he was awarded the [[King George V Silver Jubilee Medal]].<ref name="EP">{{cite news | url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19350506.2.12 | title=Official jubilee medals | date=6 May 1935 | newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] | accessdate=2 July 2013 | page=4}}</ref>
==Death== Barber died in Wellington on 15 January 1943,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19430115.2.4 | title=Deaths | date=15 January 1943 | work=Evening Post | accessdate=27 March 2016 | page=1}}</ref> and was buried at [[Karori Cemetery]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wellington.govt.nz/services/community-and-culture/cemeteries/cemeteries-search/details?id=30328&serviceType=Burial |title=Cemeteries search |date= |website= |publisher=Wellington City Council |accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{citation |first = G. F. |last = Whitcher |title = '''The New Liberal Party 1905''' [M.A.(Hons.) - University of Canterbury] |year = 1966}} *{{cite book |ref= harv |last= Wilson |first= James Oakley |title= New Zealand Parliamentary Record, 1840–1984 |edition= 4th |origyear=First published in 1913 |year= 1985 |publisher= V.R. Ward, Govt. Printer |location= Wellington |oclc= 154283103}}
==External links== *[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19360929.2.50.8 Photo of Barber driving a car], purchased from [[William McLean (New Zealand politician)|William McLean]]
{{s-start}} {{s-par|nz}} {{s-new | constituency}} {{s-ttl | title=[[Newtown (New Zealand electorate)|Member of Parliament for Newtown]] | years=1902–1908 }} {{s-non | reason=Constituency abolished}} {{end}}
